prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not being attracted to my girlfriend’s body?
I made an ALT account to ask this, since a bunch of my family follow my primary one.
I’m also.. not completely sure of the rules here, so I’ll try to keep it as PG as I can.

So, me and my girlfriend have been dating for almost 3 years. We have fun together, and we really care about each other. (just to keep it simple.)
I will say that she’s the first thin person I’ve ever been with. She’s flat, petite and pretty short. Most of the girls I’ve been with have been on the bigger side (in the good places..) and I’ve always been a fan of ... well, a bigger ~chest~ size.
This all started when me and my girlfriend were watching Netflix a few nights ago and she randomly asked me if I was okay with her having a flat chest. (She’s always been insecure about not having b**bs.) I asked why she was curious about this, and she told me she noticed that I never really had anything to say about her chest, (and that day she had been trying on lingerie and none of the ones she tried on fit her in the *chest* region. That kind of put her back mental funk where she thinks she’s not attractive if she doesn’t have a certain figure.) She said she was just curious.
I told her I had to be honest, and said that I’m not attracted to her chest size, and that I actually prefer bigger b**bs. It’s not a turn off, having a smaller size but not a turn on. If I’m being honest, that’s why I usually prefer she faces away from me during intercourse.
She was quiet for a while, and then she said she was going to go home since she had work in the morning. She texted me later on that night and told me what I said hurt her a little. She said we’ve been dating for a while and never brought this up, and that she feels like I lied to her. I told her I didn’t know what to tell her, and that I was just being honest (I was.).

Am I being the asshole here?

"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the person who wrote the story is in the wrong. The situation is about not being attracted to his girlfriend's body, specifically her chest size. They've been dating for three years, and she's the first thin person he's been with. The girlfriend brought up the topic after he didn't comment on her chest, and he admitted he prefers bigger breasts. She felt hurt and thinks he lied because he didn't mention this before.

First, I need to consider communication in relationships. It's important to discuss preferences and boundaries, but timing and delivery matter. He waited three years to mention this preference. Maybe he thought it wasn't important or didn't want to hurt her. But by not bringing it up, he might have contributed to her insecurity. She tried on lingerie that didn't fit, which made her feel unattractive, so she was seeking reassurance. His response could have been more supportive. Instead of just stating his preference, he could have acknowledged her feelings and reassured her that her worth isn't tied to her body. 

Also, the fact that he prefers facing away during intercourse might make her feel like he's avoiding intimacy. His honesty is important, but maybe he didn't express it in a way that was validating. He says he didn't know what to tell her, but in a long-term relationship, partners should anticipate each other's insecurities and communicate openly. 

On the other hand, he was honest, and it's his right to have preferences. But maybe he should have addressed her insecurities earlier or in a more compassionate way. The fact that she felt lied about suggests that his previous reassurances (if any) were lacking. 

In terms of AITA, the key points are his failure to communicate this preference earlier and his response not addressing her emotional needs. So, the answer would be A (the author is in the wrong) because he didn't handle the communication well, contributing to her hurt feelings. However, there's nuance because he was honest, but the timing and delivery were poor. The main issue is that he didn't consider her feelings when bringing up this preference after she was already vulnerable.
